docs.title: Ainalyn SDK Documentation
docs.text:
Welcome to the Ainalyn SDK documentation! The Ainalyn SDK is an Agent Definition Compiler that helps you define task-oriented agents for the Ainalyn Platform.

Critical Understanding: SDK ≠ Runtime

The Ainalyn SDK is a compiler, not a runtime execution engine. It provides tools to describe agents, not to execute them. Execution authority belongs solely to the Ainalyn Platform.

docs.title: What is Ainalyn SDK?
docs.text:
The Ainalyn SDK enables developers to:

  • Define task-oriented agents using a clean, type-safe Python API
  • Validate agent definitions against platform requirements
  • Export definitions to YAML format for platform deployment
  • Compile complete agent specifications ready for the marketplace

Think of it as a Domain-Specific Language (DSL) for agent descriptions, similar to how Terraform describes infrastructure or Kubernetes YAML describes deployments.

docs.title: 🏗️ Clean Hexagonal Architecture
docs.text: Built on solid software engineering principles with clear separation of concerns across domain, ports, adapters, and application layers.

docs.title: 🔒 Type-Safe API
docs.text: Full type hints with mypy strict mode compliance ensure compile-time safety and excellent IDE support.

docs.title: 🚀 Fluent Builder Pattern
docs.text: Intuitive, chainable APIs make agent definition both powerful and pleasant to use.

docs.title: ✅ Comprehensive Validation
docs.text: Built-in rules ensure your agent definitions comply with platform boundaries and best practices.

docs.title: 📦 YAML Export
docs.text: Compile your agent definitions to clean, validated YAML ready for platform deployment.

docs.title: 🧪 Testable Design
docs.text: Immutable entities and clear interfaces make your agent definitions easy to test.

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
from ainalyn import AgentBuilder, WorkflowBuilder, NodeBuilder

# Define a simple data analysis agent
agent = (
    AgentBuilder("DataAnalyst")
    .description("Analyzes CSV data and generates insights")
    .version("1.0.0")
    .add_workflow(
        WorkflowBuilder("analyze_data")
        .add_node(
            NodeBuilder("load_csv")
            .goal("Load and validate CSV file")
            .build()
        )
        .add_node(
            NodeBuilder("analyze")
            .goal("Perform statistical analysis")
            .depends_on("load_csv")
            .build()
        )
        .build()
    )
    .build()
)

# Validate and export
from ainalyn.api import validate, export_yaml

validate(agent)  # Ensures compliance with platform rules
yaml_output = export_yaml(agent)  # Ready for deployment

docs.title: Platform Boundaries (Critical)
docs.text:
What the SDK Cannot Do

The Ainalyn SDK CANNOT and MUST NOT:

  • ❌ Execute agents or workflows
  • ❌ Make decisions about retry, timeout, or fallback strategies
  • ❌ Calculate billing or pricing
  • ❌ Act as an autonomous AI agent
  • ❌ Generate executionId or manage execution state

The SDK is a description compiler only. All execution authority belongs to the Ainalyn Platform.

What the SDK Can Do

The Ainalyn SDK CAN and SHOULD:

  • ✅ Define agent structures and workflows
  • ✅ Validate definitions against rules
  • ✅ Export to platform-compatible YAML
  • ✅ Provide local development tools (test utilities)
  • ✅ Offer type-safe APIs for agent construction

docs.title: Documentation Files Location
docs.text:
All documentation source files are in the docs/ directory:

  • Markdown files (.md): Human-written documentation
  • Built site: Generated in site/ when you run mkdocs build
  • Configuration: mkdocs.yml at repository root

docs.title: Building Documentation Locally
docs.text:
To preview documentation on your machine:

# Install dependencies (in virtual environment)
.venv\Scripts\activate  # Windows
source .venv/bin/activate  # macOS/Linux
pip install ".[docs]"

# Build and serve
mkdocs serve

# Open browser to http://127.0.0.1:8000

The documentation will auto-reload when you edit files.

docs.title: Style Guidelines
docs.text:
Be clear and concise - Write for beginners - Use simple English - Avoid jargon when possible - Explain technical terms when first used

Use examples - Show code examples - Include expected output - Demonstrate common patterns

Structure well - Use headings (H2, H3, H4) - Use lists for multiple items - Use tables for comparisons - Use code blocks with language tags

docs.text:

agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").build()

  3. Commit and push

docs.text:

docs.title: For API Documentation
docs.text:
API documentation uses mkdocstrings to auto-generate from Python docstrings:

  1. Write good docstrings in source code (Google style)
  2. Create page that references the code
  3. The tool extracts and formats automatically

Example: 

# AgentBuilder API

::: ainalyn.adapters.primary.builders.AgentBuilder

docs.title: Documentation Deployment
docs.text:
Documentation is automatically deployed when changes are merged to master:

  1. GitHub Actions triggers on push to master
  2. MkDocs builds the documentation
  3. Result is published to GitHub Pages
  4. Available at https://docs.ainalyn.io/sdk

You don't need to deploy manually.

docs.title: Documentation Versioning Strategy
docs.text: This document describes how we manage documentation versions for the Ainalyn SDK.

docs.title: Why Version Documentation?
docs.text:
Users need documentation that matches the SDK version they're using. Without versioned docs, users may follow instructions that don't work with their installed version.

Key principle: Documentation should always match the release version to prevent confusion and errors.

docs.title: Current State (v0.1.0)
docs.text:
• Single version: Documentation is for the latest release (0.1.0)
  • Deployment: GitHub Pages with automatic deployment on main branch
  • No multi-version support yet: Will be added when we reach v0.2.0

docs.title: Future State (v0.2.0+)
docs.text:
We will use mike to manage multiple documentation versions:

# Deploy docs for version 1.0
mike deploy 1.0 latest --update-aliases

# Deploy docs for version 2.0
mike deploy 2.0 latest --update-aliases

# Set default version
mike set-default latest

docs.title: Version Naming Scheme
docs.text:
Documentation versions will follow these conventions:

SDK Version Doc Version Alias Description 0.1.x 0.1 - Patch releases share doc version 0.2.x 0.2 latest Latest stable release 1.0.x 1.0 latest, stable Major version main branch dev - Development (unreleased)

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Major.Minor only: Patch releases (0.1.0 → 0.1.1) typically don't change APIs, so they share docs
  • Aliases: latest always points to the newest stable version
  • Dev docs: Available for those who want to see upcoming features

docs.title: Current Workflow (Single Version)
docs.text:
# .github/workflows/docs.yml
on:
  push:
    branches: [master, main]

steps:
  - mkdocs build
  - deploy to gh-pages

docs.title: Future Workflow (Multi-Version with mike)
docs.text:
# Will be implemented in v0.2.0
on:
  push:
    tags: ['v*']  # Trigger on version tags

steps:
  - Install mike
  - Extract version from tag (v1.2.3 → 1.2)
  - mike deploy <version> latest
  - mike set-default latest

docs.title: Version Switcher
docs.text:
When we implement versioning, the documentation site will have a version dropdown:

┌─────────────────────────────┐
│ Ainalyn SDK Documentation   │
│                             │
│ Version: 1.0 ▼              │
│   - dev (unreleased)        │
│   - 1.0 (latest)            │
│   - 0.2                     │
│   - 0.1                     │
└─────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Implementation Timeline
docs.text: Milestone Action Timeline v0.1.0 Single-version docs (current) ✅ Completed v0.2.0 Add mike for multi-version Planned v1.0.0 Full version switcher UI Planned

docs.title: mkdocs.yml updates needed
docs.text:
# Add version provider
extra:
  version:
    provider: mike

docs.title: GitHub Actions updates needed
docs.text:
# Install mike
- name: Install mike
  run: pip install mike

# Deploy with version
- name: Deploy docs
  run: |
    VERSION=$(echo ${GITHUB_REF#refs/tags/v} | cut -d. -f1,2)
    mike deploy $VERSION latest --push --update-aliases

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Material for MkDocs Versioning - Official versioning guide
  • mike Documentation - Version management tool for MkDocs

docs.title: Questions?
docs.text:
• Why not version from the start? Answer: Keep it simple until we have multiple versions
  • Why mike? Answer: Recommended by Material for MkDocs, used by successful projects
  • What about old versions? Answer: We'll maintain docs for the last 2 major versions

Status: Single-version deployment (v0.1.0) ✅ Next: Implement mike when releasing v0.2.0

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text:
All notable changes to the Ainalyn SDK will be documented in this file.

The format is based on Keep a Changelog, and this project adheres to Semantic Versioning.

docs.title: Added
docs.text:
• Comprehensive documentation with MkDocs
  • Getting Started guides (Installation, Quickstart, Your First Agent)
  • Core Concepts documentation (Platform Boundaries, Compiler vs Runtime, Architecture, Agent Definition)
  • Example projects (basic_agent.py, multi_workflow_agent.py)

Initial release of the Ainalyn SDK.

docs.title: Core Features
docs.text:
• Builder API: Fluent builders for all entity types
  • AgentBuilder - Build agent definitions
  • WorkflowBuilder - Build workflows
  • NodeBuilder - Build nodes
  • ModuleBuilder - Build modules
  • PromptBuilder - Build prompts
  • ToolBuilder - Build tools

docs.title: Domain Entities
docs.text:
• AgentDefinition - Complete agent specification (aggregate root)
  • Workflow - Task execution workflow
  • Node - Individual task unit
  • Module - Reusable capability component
  • Prompt - LLM interaction template
  • Tool - External integration specification

docs.title: Validation
docs.text:
• Comprehensive validation rules
  • Name format validation (valid Python identifiers)
  • Semantic version validation
  • Circular dependency detection
  • Platform boundary compliance checks
  • validate() API function for agent validation

docs.title: Export
docs.text:
• YAML export functionality
  • export_yaml() API function
  • compile_agent() convenience function (validate + export)

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
• Clean Hexagonal Architecture implementation
  • Five-layer design:
  • Layer 1: Domain (pure business logic)
  • Layer 2: Ports (interface definitions)
  • Layer 3: Adapters (implementations)
  • Layer 4: Application (use cases & services)
  • Layer 5: API & CLI (public interfaces)

docs.title: CLI
docs.text:
• Command-line interface for common operations
  • Commands:
  • ainalyn validate <file> - Validate agent definition
  • ainalyn compile <file> - Compile to YAML
  • ainalyn version - Show SDK version
  • ainalyn --help - Show help

docs.title: Type Safety
docs.text:
• Full type hints throughout codebase
  • MyPy strict mode compliance
  • Protocol-based interfaces for flexibility

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
• Comprehensive test suite
  • Unit tests for all components
  • Integration tests for end-to-end flows

  • 85% code coverage

  • Separate unit and integration test directories

docs.title: Development Tools
docs.text:
• Pre-commit hooks for code quality
  • Ruff for linting and formatting
  • MyPy for type checking
  • Pytest for testing
  • Coverage for test coverage reporting

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Comprehensive README.md
  • Detailed CONTRIBUTING.md
  • Test documentation (tests/README.md)
  • Platform boundary specifications (ref-boundary/)
  • Platform Vision & System Boundary
  • Agent Definition Compiler & Runtime Forbidden Zone
  • Agent Canonical Definition
  • Execution Lifecycle & Authority
  • Execution Billing, Pricing & Revenue Boundary
  • Official Client Execution Presentation Contract

docs.title: Platform Boundary Enforcement
docs.text:
• No execution semantics
  • No platform authority
  • No billing/pricing logic
  • No autonomous agent patterns
  • Clear separation of concerns (compiler vs runtime)

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
• Runtime: PyYAML >=6.0 (only runtime dependency)
  • Development: pytest, mypy, ruff, coverage, pre-commit
  • Documentation: mkdocs, mkdocs-material, mkdocstrings[python]

docs.title: Platform Support
docs.text:
• Python 3.11, 3.12, 3.13
  • Cross-platform (Windows, macOS, Linux)

docs.title: Version Numbering
docs.text:
We use Semantic Versioning:

  • MAJOR (x.0.0): Incompatible API changes
  • MINOR (0.x.0): New features (backward compatible)
  • PATCH (0.0.x): Bug fixes (backward compatible)

docs.title: Release Process
docs.text:
1. Update CHANGELOG.md with changes
  2. Update version in pyproject.toml
  3. Create git tag (git tag v0.1.0)
  4. Push tag (git push origin v0.1.0)
  5. GitHub Actions builds and publishes to PyPI
  6. Update documentation

docs.title: Upgrading to 0.1.0
docs.text: Initial release - no migration needed.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common issues and their solutions when using the Ainalyn SDK.

docs.title: Python Version Errors
docs.text:
Problem: Error about Python version requirement

ERROR: This package requires Python >=3.11

Solution: Install Python 3.11 or higher

# Check your Python version
python --version

# Install Python 3.11+ (Ubuntu/Debian)
sudo apt install python3.11

# Install Python 3.11+ (macOS with Homebrew)
brew install python@3.11

# Windows: Download from python.org

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
Problem: Cannot install due to permissions

ERROR: Could not install packages due to an EnvironmentError: [Errno 13] Permission denied

Solution: Use a virtual environment or --user flag

# Option 1: Virtual environment (recommended)
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
pip install ainalyn-sdk

# Option 2: User install
pip install --user ainalyn-sdk

docs.title: Module Not Found
docs.text:
Problem: Cannot import ainalyn after installation

ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'ainalyn'

Solution: Ensure ainalyn is installed in the active environment

# Check if installed
pip list | grep ainalyn

# Reinstall if needed
pip uninstall ainalyn-sdk
pip install ainalyn-sdk

# Verify import works
python -c "import ainalyn; print(ainalyn.__version__)"

docs.title: Invalid Name Format
docs.text:
Problem: Validation fails due to invalid name

ValidationError: Invalid name 'my-agent': must be a valid Python identifier

Solution: Use valid Python identifiers (letters, digits, underscores)

# ❌ Wrong
AgentBuilder("my-agent")
AgentBuilder("my agent")
AgentBuilder("123agent")

# ✅ Correct
AgentBuilder("my_agent")
AgentBuilder("MyAgent")
AgentBuilder("agent123")

docs.title: Circular Dependency Detected
docs.text:
Problem: Nodes have circular dependencies

ValidationError: Circular dependency detected: A → B → A

Solution: Remove circular dependencies

# ❌ Wrong (circular)
workflow = (
    WorkflowBuilder("circular")
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("A").depends_on("B").build())
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("B").depends_on("A").build())
    .build()
)

# ✅ Correct (acyclic)
workflow = (
    WorkflowBuilder("acyclic")
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("A").build())
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("B").depends_on("A").build())
    .build()
)

docs.title: Missing Required Field
docs.text:
Problem: Required field not provided

ValidationError: Missing required field 'version'

Solution: Provide all required fields

# ❌ Wrong (missing version)
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").description("...").build()

# ✅ Correct (all required fields)
agent = (
    AgentBuilder("MyAgent")
    .description("My agent description")
    .version("1.0.0")
    .build()
)

docs.title: Invalid Version Format
docs.text:
Problem: Version doesn't follow semantic versioning

ValidationError: Invalid version format '1.0'

Solution: Use semantic versioning (major.minor.patch)

# ❌ Wrong
.version("1.0")
.version("v1.0.0")
.version("latest")

# ✅ Correct
.version("1.0.0")
.version("2.3.1")
.version("0.1.0-beta")

docs.title: Forgot to Call .build()
docs.text:
Problem: Object is a builder, not an entity

TypeError: expected Workflow, got WorkflowBuilder

Solution: Always call .build() on builders

# ❌ Wrong
workflow = WorkflowBuilder("my_workflow").add_node(...)

# ✅ Correct
workflow = WorkflowBuilder("my_workflow").add_node(...).build()

docs.title: Dependency on Non-Existent Node
docs.text:
Problem: Node depends on a node that doesn't exist

ValidationError: Dependency 'unknown_node' not found in workflow

Solution: Ensure dependency names match existing nodes

# ❌ Wrong (typo in dependency)
workflow = (
    WorkflowBuilder("my_workflow")
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("step1").build())
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("step2").depends_on("step_1").build())  # Typo!
    .build()
)

# ✅ Correct
workflow = (
    WorkflowBuilder("my_workflow")
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("step1").build())
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("step2").depends_on("step1").build())
    .build()
)

docs.title: YAML Export Fails
docs.text:
Problem: Cannot export to YAML

ExportError: Failed to export agent definition

Solution: Validate first, then export

from ainalyn.api import validate, export_yaml

# Validate before exporting
try:
    validate(agent)
    yaml_output = export_yaml(agent)
except Exception as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

docs.title: Unicode/Encoding Errors
docs.text:
Problem: Special characters cause encoding errors

UnicodeEncodeError: 'charmap' codec can't encode character

Solution: Specify UTF-8 encoding when writing files

# ❌ Wrong (default encoding)
with open("agent.yaml", "w") as f:
    f.write(yaml_output)

# ✅ Correct (UTF-8 encoding)
with open("agent.yaml", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(yaml_output)

docs.title: Command Not Found
docs.text:
Problem: ainalyn command not found

bash: ainalyn: command not found

Solution: Ensure SDK is installed and PATH is correct

# Check if installed
pip show ainalyn-sdk

# Reinstall if needed
pip install --force-reinstall ainalyn-sdk

# Check PATH (ensure Scripts directory is in PATH)
which ainalyn  # Linux/macOS
where ainalyn  # Windows

docs.title: CLI Import Errors
docs.text:
Problem: CLI fails with import errors

ImportError: cannot import name 'AgentBuilder'

Solution: Reinstall the SDK

pip uninstall ainalyn-sdk
pip install ainalyn-sdk

docs.title: MyPy Errors
docs.text:
Problem: MyPy reports type errors

error: Argument has incompatible type "str"; expected "Workflow"

Solution: Ensure proper types are used

# ❌ Wrong (passing string instead of Workflow)
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").add_workflow("my_workflow").build()

# ✅ Correct (build workflow first)
workflow = WorkflowBuilder("my_workflow").build()
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").add_workflow(workflow).build()

docs.title: Missing Type Hints
docs.text:
Problem: Type checker complains about missing hints

Solution: Import type definitions

from __future__ import annotations
from ainalyn import AgentBuilder, Workflow
from ainalyn.domain.entities import AgentDefinition

agent: AgentDefinition = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").build()

docs.title: Attempting to Execute Agent
docs.text:
Problem: Trying to call execution methods

AttributeError: 'AgentDefinition' has no attribute 'execute'

Solution: Remember the SDK is a compiler, not a runtime

# ❌ Wrong (SDK cannot execute)
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").build()
result = agent.execute()  # Method doesn't exist!

# ✅ Correct (compile to YAML for platform)
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").build()
yaml_output = export_yaml(agent)
# Upload YAML to platform for execution

docs.title: Modifying Frozen Entities
docs.text:
Problem: Cannot modify entity after creation

dataclasses.FrozenInstanceError: cannot assign to field 'name'

Solution: Entities are immutable, create new ones instead

# ❌ Wrong (cannot modify)
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").build()
agent.name = "NewName"  # Error!

# ✅ Correct (create new agent)
agent_v2 = AgentBuilder("NewName").version("2.0.0").build()

docs.title: MkDocs Not Found
docs.text:
Problem: Cannot build documentation

mkdocs: command not found

Solution: Install documentation dependencies

pip install "ainalyn-sdk[docs]"

# Or install individually
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material mkdocstrings[python]

docs.title: Build Warnings
docs.text:
Problem: Documentation builds with warnings

WARNING: Could not find cross-reference target

Solution: Check internal links and references

# Build with strict mode to catch all issues
mkdocs build --strict

docs.title: Slow Validation
docs.text:
Problem: Validation takes too long for large agents

Solution: This is expected for complex agents with many nodes

# Validation complexity grows with:
# - Number of nodes
# - Number of dependencies
# - Complexity of rules

# For very large agents, validation may take several seconds
# This is normal and ensures definition correctness

docs.title: Check the Documentation
docs.text:
• Installation Guide
  • Quickstart
  • Platform Boundaries
  • API Reference

docs.title: Report Issues
docs.text:
If you encounter a bug:

  1. Check existing issues: GitHub Issues
  2. Create a minimal reproduction: Smallest code that shows the problem
  3. Include details:
  4. SDK version (pip show ainalyn-sdk)
  5. Python version (python --version)
  6. Operating system
  7. Error messages (full traceback)
  8. Expected vs actual behavior

docs.title: Community Support
docs.text:
• GitHub Discussions: Ask questions
  • Email: dev@ainalyn.io

docs.title: Debug Checklist
docs.text:
When something goes wrong:

  • Is Python 3.11+ installed?
  • Is ainalyn-sdk installed? (pip show ainalyn-sdk)
  • Are you in the correct virtual environment?
  • Did you call .build() on all builders?
  • Are all required fields provided?
  • Are names valid Python identifiers?
  • Is the version in semantic format?
  • Are there any circular dependencies?
  • Did you validate before exporting?
  • Are file encodings set to UTF-8?

Still stuck? Don't hesitate to reach out via GitHub Issues or email!

docs.title: Agent Definition
docs.text: An Agent Definition is the complete specification of a task-oriented agent for the Ainalyn Platform. This document explains what an Agent Definition is, what it contains, and how to create one.

docs.title: What is an Agent Definition?
docs.text:
An Agent Definition is a description of an agent's structure, capabilities, and workflows. It is NOT an executing system—it's a blueprint that the platform uses to create executions.

agent_definition = AgentDefinition(
    name="MyAgent",
    version="1.0.0",
    description="What the agent does",
    workflows=(...),   # How the agent works
    modules=(...),     # Reusable capabilities
    prompts=(...),     # LLM guidance
    tools=(...),       # External integrations
)

docs.title: 1. Agent Metadata
docs.text:
Every agent has basic metadata:

agent = (
    AgentBuilder("TaskAgent")
    .description("Automates repetitive tasks efficiently")
    .version("2.1.0")
    .build()
)

Fields: - name (required): Unique identifier (valid Python identifier) - version (required): Semantic version (e.g., "1.0.0", "2.3.1") - description (required): Human-readable description

docs.title: 2. Workflows
docs.text:
Workflows define the task execution logic:

workflow = WorkflowBuilder("main_flow")
    .description("Primary task workflow")
    .add_node(...)
    .add_node(...)
    .build()

Purpose: Organize nodes into logical execution flows

See: Defining Workflows

docs.title: 3. Nodes
docs.text:
Nodes are the smallest units of work:

node = NodeBuilder("process_data")
    .goal("Process and clean the input data")
    .description("Additional context...")
    .depends_on("load_data")
    .build()

Purpose: Represent individual sub-tasks

See: Creating Nodes

docs.title: 4. Modules
docs.text:
Modules provide reusable capabilities:

module = ModuleBuilder("DataProcessor")
    .description("Reusable data processing capabilities")
    .add_capability("parse_csv")
    .add_capability("validate_schema")
    .build()

Purpose: Share common functionality across workflows

See: Adding Modules

docs.title: 5. Prompts
docs.text:
Prompts guide LLM behavior:

prompt = PromptBuilder("analysis_prompt")
    .template("Analyze the following data: {data}")
    .build()

Purpose: Define LLM interaction templates

docs.title: 6. Tools
docs.text:
Tools specify external integrations:

tool = ToolBuilder("api_caller")
    .description("Calls external REST APIs")
    .add_parameter("url")
    .add_parameter("method")
    .build()

Purpose: Declare external capabilities needed

docs.title: Agent Definition Structure
docs.text:
Here's the complete entity structure:

@dataclass(frozen=True)
class AgentDefinition:
    """Complete agent specification."""

    # Required metadata
    name: str                           # Agent identifier
    version: str                        # Semantic version
    description: str                    # What the agent does

    # Optional components (default to empty tuples)
    workflows: tuple[Workflow, ...] = field(default_factory=tuple)
    modules: tuple[Module, ...] = field(default_factory=tuple)
    prompts: tuple[Prompt, ...] = field(default_factory=tuple)
    tools: tuple[Tool, ...] = field(default_factory=tuple)

docs.title: Minimal Valid Agent
docs.text:
The absolute minimum agent definition:

agent = (
    AgentBuilder("MinimalAgent")
    .description("A minimal agent")
    .version("1.0.0")
    .build()
)

Note: While valid, a useful agent needs at least one workflow!

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
A realistic agent with all components:

from ainalyn import (
    AgentBuilder,
    WorkflowBuilder,
    NodeBuilder,
    ModuleBuilder,
    PromptBuilder,
    ToolBuilder,
)

# Define a reusable module
csv_module = (
    ModuleBuilder("CSVProcessor")
    .description("CSV file processing capabilities")
    .add_capability("read_csv")
    .add_capability("validate_csv")
    .build()
)

# Define a prompt
analysis_prompt = (
    PromptBuilder("data_analysis")
    .template("Analyze this data and provide insights: {data}")
    .build()
)

# Define a tool
api_tool = (
    ToolBuilder("rest_api")
    .description("REST API integration")
    .add_parameter("endpoint")
    .build()
)

# Define workflow nodes
load_node = (
    NodeBuilder("load_data")
    .goal("Load data from CSV file")
    .build()
)

analyze_node = (
    NodeBuilder("analyze_data")
    .goal("Perform statistical analysis")
    .depends_on("load_data")
    .build()
)

report_node = (
    NodeBuilder("generate_report")
    .goal("Create analysis report")
    .depends_on("analyze_data")
    .build()
)

# Define workflow
analysis_workflow = (
    WorkflowBuilder("analyze_csv")
    .description("Load, analyze, and report on CSV data")
    .add_node(load_node)
    .add_node(analyze_node)
    .add_node(report_node)
    .build()
)

# Create complete agent
data_analyst = (
    AgentBuilder("DataAnalyst")
    .description("Automated CSV data analysis and reporting")
    .version("1.0.0")
    .add_workflow(analysis_workflow)
    .add_module(csv_module)
    .add_prompt(analysis_prompt)
    .add_tool(api_tool)
    .build()
)

docs.title: YAML Representation
docs.text:
When exported, the agent definition becomes:

name: DataAnalyst
version: 1.0.0
description: Automated CSV data analysis and reporting

workflows:
  - name: analyze_csv
    description: Load, analyze, and report on CSV data
    nodes:
      - name: load_data
        goal: Load data from CSV file
        dependencies: []
      - name: analyze_data
        goal: Perform statistical analysis
        dependencies: [load_data]
      - name: generate_report
        goal: Create analysis report
        dependencies: [analyze_data]

modules:
  - name: CSVProcessor
    description: CSV file processing capabilities
    capabilities: [read_csv, validate_csv]

prompts:
  - name: data_analysis
    template: "Analyze this data and provide insights: {data}"

tools:
  - name: rest_api
    description: REST API integration
    parameters: [endpoint]

docs.title: What an Agent Definition is NOT
docs.text:
Critical Distinctions

An Agent Definition is NOT:

  • ❌ An executing process
  • ❌ A runtime system
  • ❌ An autonomous agent
  • ❌ A service or API
  • ❌ A workflow engine

It IS:

  • ✅ A specification
  • ✅ A description
  • ✅ A blueprint
  • ✅ A configuration
  • ✅ A deployment artifact

docs.title: 1. Naming Rules
docs.text:
All names must be valid Python identifiers:

# ✅ Valid names
"MyAgent"
"data_processor"
"agent_v2"

# ❌ Invalid names
"my-agent"       # No hyphens
"my agent"       # No spaces
"123agent"       # Cannot start with digit

docs.title: 2. Semantic Versioning
docs.text:
Versions must follow semantic versioning:

# ✅ Valid versions
"1.0.0"
"2.3.1"
"0.1.0-beta"

# ❌ Invalid versions
"1.0"            # Must have three parts
"v1.0.0"         # No 'v' prefix
"latest"         # Must be specific

docs.title: 3. No Circular Dependencies
docs.text:
Workflow nodes cannot have circular dependencies:

# ❌ Invalid (circular)
workflow = (
    WorkflowBuilder("circular")
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("A").depends_on("B").build())
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("B").depends_on("A").build())  # A→B→A
    .build()
)

# ✅ Valid (acyclic)
workflow = (
    WorkflowBuilder("linear")
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("A").build())
    .add_node(NodeBuilder("B").depends_on("A").build())  # A→B
    .build()
)

docs.title: 4. Platform Boundary Compliance
docs.text:
Definitions must not include forbidden patterns:

# ❌ Forbidden (execution semantics)
class MyAgent:
    def execute(self): ...  # No execution methods!

# ✅ Allowed (description only)
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent")....build()  # Pure description

docs.title: The Agent as a Product
docs.text:
On the Ainalyn Platform, agents are marketplace products:

  • Discoverable: Users can find your agent
  • Schedulable: Users can request execution
  • Billable: Platform charges for executions
  • Governed: Platform enforces policies

Your Agent Definition becomes a product listing!

docs.title: Immutability
docs.text:
All agent definitions are immutable (frozen dataclasses):

agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent")....build()

# ❌ Cannot modify
agent.name = "NewName"  # Error: frozen dataclass

# ✅ Create new version
agent_v2 = (
    AgentBuilder("MyAgent")
    .version("2.0.0")  # New version
    .build()
)

Why?: Immutability ensures definitions are stable and reproducible.

docs.title: Validation
docs.text:
Always validate before deployment:

from ainalyn.api import validate

try:
    validate(agent)
    print("✅ Valid agent definition")
except ValidationError as e:
    print(f"❌ Validation failed: {e}")

Validation checks: - Name format - Version format - No circular dependencies - Required fields present - Platform boundary compliance

docs.title: 1. Clear Goals
docs.text:
Every node should have a specific, measurable goal:

# ✅ Good goal
.goal("Extract all email addresses from the input text")

# ❌ Vague goal
.goal("Process data")

docs.title: 2. Semantic Versioning
docs.text:
Update versions meaningfully:

  • Major (1.0.0 → 2.0.0): Breaking changes
  • Minor (1.0.0 → 1.1.0): New features
  • Patch (1.0.0 → 1.0.1): Bug fixes

docs.title: 3. Descriptive Names
docs.text:
Use self-documenting names:

# ✅ Clear names
NodeBuilder("validate_email_format")
WorkflowBuilder("process_customer_orders")

# ❌ Unclear names
NodeBuilder("step1")
WorkflowBuilder("main")

docs.title: 4. Modular Design
docs.text:
Reuse modules across workflows:

auth_module = ModuleBuilder("Authentication")....build()

agent = (
    AgentBuilder("MyAgent")
    .add_module(auth_module)  # Reusable!
    .add_workflow(workflow1)
    .add_workflow(workflow2)  # Both can use auth_module
    .build()
)

docs.title: 5. Include Documentation
docs.text:
Add descriptions everywhere:

workflow = (
    WorkflowBuilder("data_pipeline")
    .description("ETL pipeline for customer data")  # Helpful!
    .add_node(...)
    .build()
)

docs.title: Further Reading
docs.text:
• Using Builder API - How to build definitions
  • Validation - Validating definitions
  • Platform Boundaries - What definitions cannot include
  • Examples - Complete example definitions

An Agent Definition is your blueprint for success on the Ainalyn Platform! 📋

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: The Ainalyn SDK is built on Hexagonal Architecture (also known as Ports and Adapters), ensuring clean separation of concerns and maintainability.

docs.title: Layer 1: Domain (Core Business Logic)
docs.text:
Location: ainalyn/domain/

Purpose: Pure business entities and rules with NO external dependencies

Components: - Entities (entities/): Immutable frozen dataclasses - AgentDefinition - The aggregate root - Workflow, Node, Module, Prompt, Tool - Rules (rules/): Domain validation logic - Naming conventions - Circular dependency detection - Platform boundary enforcement

Key Characteristics: - ✅ Frozen dataclasses (immutable) - ✅ No external dependencies - ✅ Pure Python types - ✅ 100% type-safe

Example: 

@dataclass(frozen=True)
class AgentDefinition:
    """Agent Definition - The aggregate root.

    NOTE: This is a DESCRIPTION entity, not a runtime implementation.
    """
    name: str
    version: str
    description: str
    workflows: tuple[Workflow, ...]
    modules: tuple[Module, ...]
    prompts: tuple[Prompt, ...]
    tools: tuple[Tool, ...]

docs.title: Layer 2: Ports (Interface Definitions)
docs.text:
Location: ainalyn/ports/

Purpose: Define contracts between layers using Python Protocols

Components: - Inbound Ports (inbound/): How external world uses the SDK - Builder - Interface for building entities - Validator - Interface for validation - Exporter - Interface for export - Outbound Ports (outbound/): How SDK uses external services - Writer - File writing interface - SchemaValidator - Schema validation interface

Key Characteristics: - ✅ Protocol-based (duck typing) - ✅ No implementations - ✅ Dependency Inversion Principle

Example: 

class Builder(Protocol[T]):
    """Protocol for builder pattern."""

    def build(self) -> T:
        """Build and return the entity."""
        ...

docs.title: Layer 3: Adapters (Implementations)
docs.text:
Location: ainalyn/adapters/

Purpose: Implement the port interfaces

Components: - Primary Adapters (primary/): Entry points - AgentBuilder, WorkflowBuilder, NodeBuilder, etc. - BuilderError, ValidationError - Secondary Adapters (secondary/): Infrastructure - YamlExporter - YAML export implementation - SchemaValidator - JSON Schema validation - StaticAnalyzer - Code analysis

Key Characteristics: - ✅ Implements Protocol interfaces - ✅ Handles external interactions - ✅ Converts between layers

Example: 

class AgentBuilder:
    """Fluent builder for AgentDefinition."""

    def __init__(self, name: str) -> None:
        self._name = name
        self._workflows: list[Workflow] = []
        # ...

    def add_workflow(self, workflow: Workflow) -> AgentBuilder:
        """Add a workflow (fluent interface)."""
        self._workflows.append(workflow)
        return self

    def build(self) -> AgentDefinition:
        """Build the AgentDefinition."""
        return AgentDefinition(
            name=self._name,
            workflows=tuple(self._workflows),
            # ...
        )

docs.title: Layer 4: Application (Use Cases & Services)
docs.text:
Location: ainalyn/application/

Purpose: Orchestrate domain logic and adapters

Components: - DefinitionService - Core service coordinating operations - Use Cases (use_cases/): - ValidateDefinitionUseCase - ExportDefinitionUseCase - CompileDefinitionUseCase

Key Characteristics: - ✅ Orchestrates workflows - ✅ No business logic (delegates to domain) - ✅ Dependency injection

Example: 

class DefinitionService:
    """Service for agent definition operations."""

    def __init__(
        self,
        validator: Validator,
        exporter: Exporter,
    ) -> None:
        self._validator = validator
        self._exporter = exporter

    def compile(self, definition: AgentDefinition) -> str:
        """Validate and export definition."""
        self._validator.validate(definition)
        return self._exporter.export(definition)

docs.title: Layer 5: Public API & CLI
docs.text:
Location: ainalyn/api.py, ainalyn/cli.py, ainalyn/__init__.py

Purpose: Provide convenient entry points for users

Components: - api.py - High-level functions (validate(), export_yaml()) - cli.py - Command-line interface - __init__.py - Public exports

Key Characteristics: - ✅ User-friendly interfaces - ✅ Minimal logic (delegates to layers below) - ✅ Clear public API

Example: 

# api.py
def validate(definition: AgentDefinition) -> None:
    """Validate an agent definition."""
    service = _get_service()
    service.validate(definition)

def export_yaml(definition: AgentDefinition) -> str:
    """Export definition to YAML."""
    service = _get_service()
    return service.export_yaml(definition)

docs.title: Dependency Flow
docs.text:
Dependencies always point inward:

API/CLI
  ↓
Application
  ↓
Adapters
  ↓
Ports (interfaces)
  ↓
Domain (pure logic)

Why?: The domain layer has zero dependencies, making it: - Easy to test - Easy to understand - Easy to change - Stable and reliable

docs.title: 1. Builder Pattern
docs.text:
Used for entity construction:

agent = (
    AgentBuilder("MyAgent")
    .description("...")
    .version("1.0.0")
    .add_workflow(...)
    .build()
)

docs.title: 2. Protocol Pattern (Interface Segregation)
docs.text:
Used for defining interfaces:

class Validator(Protocol):
    def validate(self, definition: AgentDefinition) -> None: ...

docs.title: 3. Singleton Pattern
docs.text:
Used for the main service:

# Module-level singleton
_service: DefinitionService | None = None

def _get_service() -> DefinitionService:
    global _service
    if _service is None:
        _service = DefinitionService(...)
    return _service

docs.title: 4. Immutability Pattern
docs.text:
All entities are frozen:

@dataclass(frozen=True)
class Workflow:
    name: str
    nodes: tuple[Node, ...]  # Immutable tuple

docs.title: 5. Use Case Pattern
docs.text:
Encapsulates application logic:

class ValidateDefinitionUseCase:
    def execute(self, definition: AgentDefinition) -> None:
        # Validation logic
        ...

docs.title: Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)
docs.text:
Each class/module has one reason to change:

  • AgentBuilder: Build agents
  • YamlExporter: Export YAML
  • DefinitionRules: Validate rules

docs.title: Open/Closed Principle (OCP)
docs.text:
Entities are frozen (closed for modification):

@dataclass(frozen=True)  # Cannot be modified
class AgentDefinition:
    ...

docs.title: Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)
docs.text:
Any Validator implementation works:

def validate_agent(validator: Validator, agent: AgentDefinition) -> None:
    validator.validate(agent)  # Any validator works

docs.title: Interface Segregation Principle (ISP)
docs.text:
Small, focused protocols:

class Builder(Protocol[T]):
    def build(self) -> T: ...

class Validator(Protocol):
    def validate(self, definition: AgentDefinition) -> None: ...

docs.title: Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP)
docs.text:
Depend on abstractions (Protocols), not concretions:

class DefinitionService:
    def __init__(self, validator: Validator, exporter: Exporter):
        # Depends on protocols, not concrete classes
        ...

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
1. Testability: Each layer can be tested independently
  2. Maintainability: Changes in one layer don't cascade
  3. Flexibility: Easy to swap implementations
  4. Clarity: Clear separation of concerns

docs.title: Example: Swapping Exporters
docs.text:
Want to add JSON export? Just implement the Exporter protocol:

class JsonExporter:
    """JSON export implementation."""

    def export(self, definition: AgentDefinition) -> str:
        # JSON export logic
        ...

No changes needed to: - Domain layer - Application layer - API layer

docs.title: Type Safety
docs.text:
The SDK uses strict type checking:

# pyproject.toml
[tool.mypy]
strict = true
disallow_any_unimported = true
disallow_untyped_defs = true

Benefits: - Catch errors at development time - Excellent IDE support - Self-documenting code

docs.title: Unit Tests
docs.text:
Test each layer independently:

def test_agent_builder():
    """Test AgentBuilder in isolation."""
    builder = AgentBuilder("TestAgent")
    agent = builder.version("1.0.0").build()
    assert agent.name == "TestAgent"

docs.title: Integration Tests
docs.text:
Test layer interactions:

def test_compile_agent():
    """Test full compilation flow."""
    agent = AgentBuilder("TestAgent")....build()
    yaml_output = export_yaml(agent)
    assert "name: TestAgent" in yaml_output

docs.title: Package Structure
docs.text:
ainalyn/
├── domain/                    # Layer 1: Pure business logic
│   ├── entities/
│   │   ├── agent_definition.py
│   │   ├── workflow.py
│   │   ├── node.py
│   │   └── ...
│   └── rules/
│       └── definition_rules.py
│
├── ports/                     # Layer 2: Interfaces
│   ├── inbound/
│   │   ├── builder.py
│   │   ├── validator.py
│   │   └── exporter.py
│   └── outbound/
│       ├── writer.py
│       └── schema_validator.py
│
├── adapters/                  # Layer 3: Implementations
│   ├── primary/
│   │   ├── builders.py
│   │   └── errors.py
│   └── secondary/
│       ├── validators.py
│       ├── exporters.py
│       └── analyzers.py
│
├── application/               # Layer 4: Use cases
│   ├── services.py
│   └── use_cases/
│       ├── validate_definition.py
│       ├── export_definition.py
│       └── compile_definition.py
│
├── api.py                     # Layer 5: Public API
├── cli.py                     # Layer 5: CLI
└── __init__.py               # Layer 5: Exports

docs.title: Building and Exporting an Agent
docs.text:
1. User calls AgentBuilder()           [Layer 5: API]
         ↓
2. AgentBuilder constructs             [Layer 3: Adapter]
         ↓
3. .build() creates AgentDefinition    [Layer 1: Domain]
         ↓
4. User calls export_yaml()            [Layer 5: API]
         ↓
5. DefinitionService orchestrates      [Layer 4: Application]
         ↓
6. YamlExporter exports                [Layer 3: Adapter]
         ↓
7. YAML string returned to user        [Layer 5: API]

docs.title: Further Reading
docs.text:
• Domain Layer - Detailed domain layer docs
  • Ports Layer - Protocol definitions
  • Adapters Layer - Implementations
  • Application Layer - Use cases
  • API Layer - Public interfaces

The architecture ensures the SDK remains a focused, reliable compiler for agent definitions! 🏗️

docs.title: Compiler vs Runtime
docs.text: The Ainalyn SDK is fundamentally a compiler, not a runtime engine. Understanding this distinction is essential for effective agent development.

docs.title: What is a Compiler?
docs.text:
A compiler transforms source code from one form to another without executing it:

Source Code → [Compiler] → Target Format

docs.title: The Ainalyn SDK as a Compiler
docs.text:
Python API → [Ainalyn SDK] → YAML Definition

The SDK takes your Python-based agent descriptions and compiles them into YAML that the platform can deploy and execute.

docs.title: Analogy: Terraform
docs.text: The Ainalyn SDK is similar to Terraform:

docs.title: Terraform
docs.text:
# Terraform describes infrastructure
resource "aws_instance" "web" {
  ami           = "ami-123456"
  instance_type = "t2.micro"
}
  • Terraform does NOT: Create AWS instances itself
  • Terraform DOES: Generate a plan that AWS can execute
  • AWS does: Actually create and manage resources

docs.title: Ainalyn SDK
docs.text:
# Ainalyn SDK describes agents
agent = (
    AgentBuilder("MyAgent")
    .add_workflow(...)
    .build()
)
  • SDK does NOT: Execute agents
  • SDK DOES: Generate YAML that the platform can execute
  • Platform does: Actually run agents and manage executions

docs.title: Compiler vs Runtime Comparison
docs.text: Aspect Compiler (SDK) Runtime (Platform) Purpose Transform definitions Execute tasks Input Python API calls YAML definitions Output YAML files Execution results When Development time Production time Where Developer's machine Cloud platform Authority Structure validation Execution control

docs.title: ✅ You CAN
docs.text:
• Define agent structures
  • Validate definitions
  • Export to YAML
  • Test definition structure locally

docs.title: ❌ You CANNOT
docs.text:
• Execute agents
  • See execution results
  • Control retry/timeout
  • Calculate actual costs

docs.title: The Development Flow
docs.text:
1. Write Python code using SDK  ──────┐
                                      │
2. SDK validates structure      ◄─────┘
                                      │
3. SDK compiles to YAML         ◄─────┘
                                      │
4. Upload YAML to platform      ──────┐
                                      │
5. Platform validates definition ◄────┘
                                      │
6. User requests execution      ──────┐
                                      │
7. Platform creates Execution   ◄─────┘
                                      │
8. Platform runs agent logic    ◄─────┘
                                      │
9. Platform bills for execution ◄─────┘

SDK involvement: Steps 1-3 only!

docs.title: ❌ Wrong Mental Model
docs.text:
# Wrong thinking: "The SDK will run this"
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").add_workflow(...).build()
agent.execute()  # ❌ Does not exist!

docs.title: ✅ Correct Mental Model
docs.text:
# Correct thinking: "The SDK compiles this for the platform"
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").add_workflow(...).build()
yaml_output = export_yaml(agent)  # ✅ Compile to YAML
# Now upload YAML to platform for execution

docs.title: ❌ Wrong Approach
docs.text:
# Wrong: Trying to "run" the agent locally
result = agent.run_workflow("my_workflow")  # ❌ Not possible

docs.title: ✅ Correct Approach
docs.text:
# Correct: Validate the structure
from ainalyn.api import validate

validate(agent)  # ✅ Structural validation only
print("Agent definition is valid!")
# Actual execution happens on the platform

docs.title: 1. Separation of Concerns
docs.text:
• SDK: Focuses on definition quality
  • Platform: Focuses on execution reliability

docs.title: 2. Platform Flexibility
docs.text:
• Platform can improve execution without SDK changes
  • Platform can add new execution strategies
  • Platform can optimize resource usage

docs.title: 3. Developer Simplicity
docs.text:
• You don't manage infrastructure
  • You don't implement retry logic
  • You don't handle billing

docs.title: 4. Security and Governance
docs.text:
• Platform controls execution environment
  • Platform enforces resource limits
  • Platform ensures billing accuracy

docs.title: Local Development
docs.text:
# Development: Create and validate definitions
agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent")....build()
validate(agent)
yaml = export_yaml(agent)
print(yaml)  # Review the output

Purpose: Ensure your definition is valid and complete

docs.title: Production
docs.text:
# Production: Platform executes the definition
# (After you upload the YAML)

# Platform parses YAML
# Platform creates Execution
# Platform runs agent logic
# Platform returns results
# Platform bills user

Purpose: Actual task completion

docs.title: Q: Can I test my agent locally before deploying?
docs.text: A: You can validate the structure of your agent definition locally using validate(). However, actual agent behavior can only be tested on the platform, as the SDK cannot execute agents.

docs.title: Q: How do I debug my agent?
docs.text: A: 1. Use validate() to catch structural errors 2. Review the generated YAML for correctness 3. Deploy to platform and check execution logs 4. Platform provides execution debugging tools

docs.title: Q: Can I simulate execution locally?
docs.text: A: The SDK may provide structural validation utilities for development, but these are NOT simulations of actual platform execution. Real execution behavior depends on platform runtime, which the SDK cannot replicate.

docs.title: Q: Why not include a runtime in the SDK?
docs.text: A: Including a runtime would: - Violate platform boundaries - Create inconsistency between local and platform behavior - Require duplicating platform logic - Make the SDK unnecessarily complex - Confuse responsibility (who handles errors, billing, etc.)

docs.title: 1. Fast Feedback
docs.text:
Validation happens instantly:

validate(agent)  # Immediate structural feedback

docs.title: 2. Type Safety
docs.text:
Python type hints catch errors at development time:

builder: AgentBuilder = AgentBuilder("MyAgent")
# IDE helps you avoid mistakes

docs.title: 3. Version Control
docs.text:
Agent definitions are just code:

git add my_agent.py
git commit -m "Add new agent definition"
git push

docs.title: 4. Reproducibility
docs.text:
Same Python code always produces same YAML:

# Deterministic compilation
yaml1 = export_yaml(agent)
yaml2 = export_yaml(agent)
assert yaml1 == yaml2  # Always true

docs.title: Step 1: Builder API
docs.text:
from ainalyn import AgentBuilder

agent = AgentBuilder("MyAgent").description("...").build()

What happens: Python objects created in memory

docs.title: Step 2: Validation
docs.text:
from ainalyn.api import validate

validate(agent)

What happens: Rules engine checks compliance

docs.title: Step 3: Compilation
docs.text:
from ainalyn.api import export_yaml

yaml_output = export_yaml(agent)

What happens: Python objects transformed to YAML

docs.title: Step 4: Deployment
docs.text:
# Upload YAML to platform (via CLI, web UI, or API)
ainalyn deploy my_agent.yaml

What happens: Platform ingests and prepares for execution

docs.title: SDK as a Language
docs.text:
Think of the SDK as a Domain-Specific Language (DSL) for agent definitions:

# This is a language for describing agents
agent = (
    AgentBuilder("DataAnalyzer")
    .version("1.0.0")
    .add_workflow(
        WorkflowBuilder("analyze")
        .add_node(
            NodeBuilder("load_data")
            .goal("Load CSV data")
            .build()
        )
        .build()
    )
    .build()
)

Just like: - SQL describes queries (database executes) - HTML describes pages (browser renders) - Terraform describes infrastructure (cloud executes)

Ainalyn SDK describes agents (platform executes)

docs.title: Further Reading
docs.text:
• Platform Boundaries - What the SDK cannot do
  • Agent Definition - What you're building
  • Architecture Overview - How the SDK works
  • Validation - Validating definitions
  • Exporting - Compiling to YAML

Remember: You're not writing an execution engine. You're defining what should be executed. The platform handles the rest! 🚀

docs.title: Platform Boundaries
docs.text:
Understanding the boundaries between the Ainalyn SDK and the Ainalyn Platform is critical for successful agent development. This document defines what the SDK can and cannot do.

Most Important Concept

The SDK is a compiler, NOT a runtime. Everything you build with the SDK is a description of an agent, not an executing system. Execution authority belongs solely to the Ainalyn Platform.

docs.title: The Four Core Concepts
docs.text: The Ainalyn ecosystem is built on four foundational concepts:

docs.title: 1. Agent (Marketplace Contract Entity)
docs.text:
• What it is: A task-oriented product entity that can be scheduled, governed, and billed
  • SDK role: Define the agent's structure and capabilities
  • Platform role: Host, manage, and enable execution of agents

Agent ≠

  • ❌ Not a workflow
  • ❌ Not a node or module
  • ❌ Not an LLM or autonomous system
  • ❌ Not a runtime process

docs.title: 2. Agent Definition (Description Layer Only)
docs.text:
• What it is: The specification of an agent's structure, workflows, and capabilities
  • SDK role: Compile valid agent definitions to YAML
  • Platform role: Parse and validate definitions for deployment

SDK Creates Agent Definitions

This is the entire scope of the SDK: creating valid AgentDefinition objects and exporting them to YAML.

docs.title: 3. Execution (Platform Core Only)
docs.text:
• What it is: The runtime instance of an agent performing a task
  • SDK role: NONE - The SDK cannot execute anything
  • Platform role: Create, manage, and complete executions

Critical Distinction

  • AgentDefinition (SDK) ≠ Execution (Platform)
  • You define agents, the platform executes them
  • SDK has ZERO authority over execution

docs.title: 4. Billing (Execution-Based Only)
docs.text:
• What it is: Charges based on completed executions
  • SDK role: NONE - The SDK cannot calculate billing
  • Platform role: Track execution costs and bill users

docs.title: What the SDK CAN Do
docs.text: The SDK is authorized to:

docs.title: ✅ Define Agent Structures
docs.text:
from ainalyn import AgentBuilder, WorkflowBuilder, NodeBuilder

agent = (
    AgentBuilder("MyAgent")
    .description("What the agent does")
    .version("1.0.0")
    .add_workflow(...)
    .build()
)

docs.title: ✅ Validate Definitions
docs.text:
from ainalyn.api import validate

validate(agent)  # Ensures compliance with platform rules

docs.title: ✅ Export to YAML
docs.text:
from ainalyn.api import export_yaml

yaml_output = export_yaml(agent)  # Platform-compatible format

docs.title: ✅ Provide Local Development Tools
docs.text:
# Testing utilities (for development only)
from ainalyn.adapters.secondary import StaticAnalyzer

analyzer = StaticAnalyzer()
issues = analyzer.analyze(agent)  # Find potential problems

docs.title: ✅ Offer Type-Safe APIs
docs.text:
# Full type hints for IDE support
from ainalyn import AgentBuilder

builder: AgentBuilder = AgentBuilder("MyAgent")  # Type-safe!

docs.title: What the SDK CANNOT Do (Forbidden Zone)
docs.text: The SDK is explicitly forbidden from:

docs.title: ❌ Execution Semantics
docs.text:
NO execution methods:

# ❌ FORBIDDEN - These methods do NOT exist
agent.execute()
agent.run()
agent.start()
workflow.execute()
node.run()

Why? Execution is the platform's exclusive responsibility. The SDK only describes what should be executed, not how or when.

docs.title: ❌ Execution Authority
docs.text:
NO decisions about:

  • Retry strategies
  • Timeout policies
  • Fallback mechanisms
  • Success/failure determination
  • Execution scheduling
  • Resource allocation

Why? The platform must have sole authority over these operational decisions to ensure consistency, reliability, and governance.

docs.title: ❌ Billing and Pricing Logic
docs.text:
NO billing calculations:

# ❌ FORBIDDEN - Cannot exist in SDK
agent.calculate_cost()
execution.get_price()
agent.set_pricing(...)

Why? Billing is based on platform-managed executions, not agent definitions. The SDK cannot know execution costs.

docs.title: ❌ Autonomous Agent Patterns
docs.text:
NO autonomous behaviors:

  • Self-triggered executions
  • Continuous running loops
  • Independent decision-making
  • State persistence across executions

Why? Agents on the Ainalyn Platform are task-oriented, not autonomous. They execute specific tasks on demand, then complete.

docs.title: ❌ Execution ID Generation
docs.text:
NO execution tracking:

# ❌ FORBIDDEN
agent.create_execution_id()
agent.track_execution(...)

Why? Only the platform can create and manage executionIds, which are used for billing, tracking, and governance.

docs.title: ❌ Platform Authority
docs.text:
NO platform-level operations:

  • Agent marketplace operations
  • User authentication/authorization
  • Platform configuration
  • Infrastructure management

Why? These are platform responsibilities, far beyond the SDK's scope as a compiler.

docs.title: SDK Responsibilities
docs.text:
1. Define: Provide APIs for defining agents
  2. Validate: Ensure definitions comply with rules
  3. Compile: Export to platform-compatible YAML
  4. Document: Help developers understand boundaries

docs.title: Platform Responsibilities
docs.text:
1. Execute: Run agent definitions as executions
  2. Bill: Charge for execution completion
  3. Govern: Enforce policies and limits
  4. Host: Provide infrastructure and marketplace

docs.title: Local Testing vs Platform Execution
docs.text:
Critical Distinction

Local run ≠ Platform execution

docs.title: Local Testing (SDK Development Mode)
docs.text:
# For development ONLY
# NOT representative of platform execution!

# You might create test utilities
def test_agent_structure(agent):
    """Test that agent definition is well-formed."""
    assert agent.name
    assert len(agent.workflows) > 0
    # etc.

Purpose: Validate structure, not behavior

docs.title: Platform Execution (Production)
docs.text:
• Agent definition is deployed to platform
  • Platform parses YAML
  • Platform creates Execution instances
  • Platform manages execution lifecycle
  • Platform bills based on execution results

Purpose: Actual task completion

docs.title: Execution Lifecycle (Platform Only)
docs.text:
The platform manages this lifecycle (SDK has no role):

REQUESTED → VALIDATED → SCHEDULED → RUNNING → COMPLETED/FAILED/ABORTED
  1. REQUESTED: User requests task execution
  2. VALIDATED: Platform validates request
  3. SCHEDULED: Platform schedules execution
  4. RUNNING: Platform executes agent logic
  5. COMPLETED/FAILED/ABORTED: Platform finalizes execution

SDK involvement: NONE. The SDK's work ends at agent definition compilation.

docs.title: EIP (Execution Implementation Provider)
docs.text:
EIPs provide execution capabilities but NOT execution authority:

  • EIP provides: LLM APIs, tool integrations, compute resources
  • Platform decides: When to use EIP, retry logic, timeout handling
  • SDK role: NONE - EIP is a platform concept

docs.title: Boundary Compliance Checklist
docs.text:
When developing with the SDK, ensure:

  • ✅ No execution-related methods (execute(), run(), start())
  • ✅ No state management across executions
  • ✅ No billing/pricing calculations
  • ✅ No executionId generation or tracking
  • ✅ No platform authority operations
  • ✅ All agent definitions include disclaimer comments
  • ✅ Documentation emphasizes "compiler, not runtime"

docs.title: Disclaimer Requirements
docs.text:
All agent definitions should include a disclaimer:

"""
MyAgent - A task-oriented agent.

IMPORTANT: This is an agent DEFINITION, not a runtime implementation.
Execution authority belongs to the Ainalyn Platform.
"""

docs.title: 1. Clear Responsibility
docs.text:
• SDK: Definition quality
  • Platform: Execution reliability
  • No confusion about who handles what

docs.title: 2. Platform Governance
docs.text:
• Platform can enforce policies consistently
  • Platform can evolve execution strategies
  • Platform can ensure billing accuracy

docs.title: 3. Developer Focus
docs.text:
• Developers focus on agent logic
  • Developers don't manage infrastructure
  • Developers don't implement execution engines

docs.title: 4. Security and Trust
docs.text:
• Platform controls resource access
  • Platform prevents malicious execution
  • Platform ensures fair billing

docs.title: ❌ "The SDK runs my agent locally"
docs.text: Wrong. The SDK defines your agent. Local testing (if provided) is structural validation only, not actual execution.

docs.title: ❌ "I can optimize execution with SDK settings"
docs.text: Wrong. Execution optimization is the platform's job. Your agent definition describes WHAT, not HOW.

docs.title: ❌ "My agent will retry automatically"
docs.text: Wrong. Retry logic is a platform decision, not defined in your agent. The platform determines retry strategies.

docs.title: ❌ "I can estimate costs in the SDK"
docs.text: Wrong. Costs depend on platform execution, which varies based on actual runtime behavior, not static definitions.

docs.title: Further Reading
docs.text:
• Compiler vs Runtime - Deep dive into the paradigm
  • Agent Definition - What you're actually building
  • Architecture Overview - How the SDK is designed
  • Boundary Compliance - For SDK contributors

docs.title: Reference Specifications
docs.text:
These concepts are derived from the official boundary specifications:

  • ref-boundary/Platform Vision & System Boundary.md
  • ref-boundary/Agent Definition Compiler & Runtime Forbidden Zone.md
  • ref-boundary/Agent Canonical Definition.md
  • ref-boundary/Execution Lifecycle & Authority.md
  • ref-boundary/Execution Billing, Pricing & Revenue Boundary.md

Remember: The SDK is a powerful compiler for agent definitions. Stay within the boundaries, and you'll build amazing agents for the Ainalyn Platform! 🚀

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide will help you install the Ainalyn SDK and set up your development environment.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python: 3.11 or higher (3.11, 3.12, 3.13 supported)
  • pip: Latest version recommended
  • Operating System: Cross-platform (Windows, macOS, Linux)

docs.title: Install from PyPI (Recommended)
docs.text:
Install the latest stable release from PyPI:

pip install ainalyn-sdk

docs.title: Install from Source
docs.text:
For development or to use the latest unreleased features:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/ainalyn/ainalyn-sdk.git
cd ainalyn-sdk

# Install in editable mode with development dependencies
pip install -e ".[dev]"

docs.title: Install with Optional Dependencies
docs.text:
The SDK provides optional dependency groups for different use cases:

# Install with documentation tools
pip install "ainalyn-sdk[docs]"

# Install with testing tools
pip install "ainalyn-sdk[test]"

# Install with all development dependencies
pip install "ainalyn-sdk[dev]"

# Install everything (dev + docs)
pip install "ainalyn-sdk[all]"

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text: After installation, verify that the SDK is properly installed:

docs.title: Check Version
docs.text:
ainalyn --version

Expected output: 

ainalyn-sdk 0.1.0

docs.title: Check Python Import
docs.text:
python -c "import ainalyn; print(ainalyn.__version__)"

Expected output: 

0.1.0

docs.title: Verify CLI Commands
docs.text:
The SDK provides a command-line interface (CLI) for common tasks:

# Show available commands
ainalyn --help

Expected output: 

Usage: ainalyn [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

  Ainalyn SDK - Agent Definition Compiler

Commands:
  validate    Validate an agent definition file
  compile     Compile agent definition to YAML
  version     Show SDK version

docs.title: Development Setup (For Contributors)
docs.text: If you plan to contribute to the Ainalyn SDK, follow these additional setup steps:

docs.title: 1. Install Pre-commit Hooks
docs.text:
Pre-commit hooks ensure code quality before commits:

# Install pre-commit
pip install pre-commit

# Install the git hooks
pre-commit install

docs.title: 2. Verify Development Tools
docs.text:
Check that all development tools are available:

# Linting and formatting
ruff --version

# Type checking
mypy --version

# Testing
pytest --version

docs.title: 3. Run Initial Tests
docs.text:
Ensure everything is working:

# Run all tests
pytest

# Run with coverage
pytest --cov=ainalyn --cov-report=term-missing

Expected: All tests should pass with ≥85% coverage.

docs.title: Visual Studio Code
docs.text:
Recommended extensions for VS Code:

  • Python (Microsoft)
  • Pylance (Microsoft)
  • Ruff (Astral Software)
  • Python Type Hint (Robert Craigie)

Recommended settings (.vscode/settings.json):

{
  "python.linting.enabled": true,
  "python.linting.ruffEnabled": true,
  "python.formatting.provider": "none",
  "[python]": {
    "editor.defaultFormatter": "charliermarsh.ruff",
    "editor.formatOnSave": true,
    "editor.codeActionsOnSave": {
      "source.organizeImports": true,
      "source.fixAll": true
    }
  },
  "python.analysis.typeCheckingMode": "strict",
  "python.testing.pytestEnabled": true
}

docs.title: PyCharm
docs.text:
1. Configure interpreter: File → Settings → Project → Python Interpreter
  2. Enable type checking: Settings → Editor → Inspections → Python → Type Checker
  3. Configure Ruff: Settings → Tools → External Tools (add Ruff)

docs.title: Python Version Issues
docs.text:
If you see errors about Python version:

# Check your Python version
python --version

# If < 3.11, install a newer Python version
# On Ubuntu/Debian:
sudo apt install python3.11

# On macOS with Homebrew:
brew install python@3.11

# On Windows: Download from python.org

docs.title: Permission Errors
docs.text:
If you encounter permission errors during installation:

# Use --user flag
pip install --user ainalyn-sdk

# Or use a virtual environment (recommended)
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
pip install ainalyn-sdk

docs.title: Import Errors
docs.text:
If you get ModuleNotFoundError:

# Ensure ainalyn is installed
pip list | grep ainalyn

# Reinstall if needed
pip uninstall ainalyn-sdk
pip install ainalyn-sdk

docs.title: Development Dependencies Not Found
docs.text:
If development tools are missing:

# Reinstall with dev dependencies
pip install "ainalyn-sdk[dev]"

# Or install individually
pip install pytest mypy ruff pre-commit

docs.title: Virtual Environment Best Practices
docs.text: We strongly recommend using virtual environments:

docs.title: Using venv (built-in)
docs.text:
# Create virtual environment
python -m venv .venv

# Activate (Linux/macOS)
source .venv/bin/activate

# Activate (Windows)
.venv\Scripts\activate

# Install SDK
pip install ainalyn-sdk

# Deactivate when done
deactivate

docs.title: Using conda
docs.text:
# Create environment
conda create -n ainalyn python=3.11

# Activate
conda activate ainalyn

# Install SDK
pip install ainalyn-sdk

docs.title: Using poetry
docs.text:
# Initialize project
poetry init

# Add SDK
poetry add ainalyn-sdk

# Install
poetry install

docs.text:
Now that you have the SDK installed:
